transcripts.text: I'll give you the story behind this wall.  You can see where the wall goes down into the sand here, but this is what's called the floating fence.  And this was constructed in 2008 after Border Patrol agent Louie Aguilar was run over and killed out here with a stolen Humvee full of dope that the Border Patrol was trying to pull over.  was evading apprehension and they were trying to make it back into Mexico because this didn't exist here before.  And they knew they could get away.  All they had to do was get past the border patrol.  So Louie Aguilar was out here in January, 2008, near where we started up there by the road and putting out spike strips to stop the vehicle that was already being pursued by the border patrol.  The person driving the vehicle saw that Louis Aguilar was there with the spike strips and intentionally drove towards Louis Aguilar and ran over him and killed him out here in January of 2008.  Shortly after that, this wall was funded and built and placed out here.  And this area, especially in the winter, gets tens of thousands of off-road visitors from California, and Arizona that come out here and converge on this place.  more than 10 000 people out here for the week of thanksgiving and so what would happen was the uh the smugglers from mexico would try to blend in with that off-road legitimate off-road traffic in the area here in the border patrol had to keep an eye really close to the line here just to see who was going back and forth into mexico.  now with this wall here we don't have to worry about this.  we haven't had any trouble out here since we've erected this floating barrier out here in 2008 and this is a 16 foot high barrier.  uh we have to uh the sand shift out here a lot so we have to continuously keep it cleaned out.  but it's this was engineered to be able to be these sections to be lifted up and and placed back on top of the sand and stay.
so the sand kind of shifts over the top of these and then they lift them back out.  yes wow and how often does that have to happen?
hey it's uh.  we have a contract on here and whenever they see the sand start building up on it they'll come out here and remove the sand or they'll lift it up and place it back on top of the sand.
Interesting.  And so you don't think that I mean this wall.  basically this area is a lot safer now as a result of it?
Absolutely.  We have had people try to cut this and we'll replace it if they try it.
With a metal saw here?  Like this whole thing?

Yes.  Wow.  We've had them cut these right around here and try to cut all the way around.  And what they'll do is camouflage it.  And then they put hinges on the backside here that the agents can't see.  And then what they replaced, took some of these barriers out and remade the wall here to look like it's the same exact one, but using it so that they could come back and then lay it down, drive a vehicle over.  and then try to smuggle dope through this area here.  But we've always detected it before they've completed that.  Wow.
And what about, is it like basically impossible to tunnel through here because of the sand?

Because of the sand, yeah.  And these go down into the sand about four feet.  So it's impossible to dig through here because the sand just caves back in on itself.  Wow.  Awesome.  Ever since we've placed this barrier out here, we have the people that come out here for legitimate recreation are much safer and we don't have people from Mexico coming in, trying to blend in the dope smugglers, trying to blend in with that traffic and then potentially jeopardizing the safety of the people that are legitimately using this recreation
area.  Because they can't drive over basically.
Right.  Exactly.
And how long is this particular section?

There's a famous photo.  of a Jeep that they tried to ramp over this barrier here.  So they got a ramp and they built the ramp up to come over and the Jeep got stuck on the top.  And there's a famous photo of that that's been out here.  It's been out for years.
I got to find that.  16 feet?  They tried to get all the way over this thing?

Absolutely.  And they used steel ramps to ramp over and try to ramp all the way down.  Interesting story.  I was in Israel doing a border tour and working with Israelis on some of their border security.  And they pulled up a PowerPoint and they were going to give us a presentation.  And the very first picture on the PowerPoint was a picture of the Jeep that was on top of this barrier out here in Yuma, Arizona.  And I was in Israel.  That's crazy.
So is it, did you guys, do the Israelis, does their wall compare to this one?  Is it similar?  Is it bigger?  Is it?

Theirs is different.  They have the one that the parts of the wall that I've seen now, they have different variety, different varieties.  So out in the desert, they have, uh, mainly fencing.  It's reinforced fencing and it has a linear detection capability that's attached to the fence out there.  And we've tested that out here in this area as well.  And it works.
It's like a motion sensor.

Anybody messing with the fence or trying to cut it or climb over it, it has a detection signal that goes back to their command center and they go out and investigate.  These are the places that are way out in the desert, way far away from any urban areas.  And then near the urban areas and the places that I've seen over there, they use concrete barrier in some places around Gaza and those areas because of the threat of shooting through the barrier.  We haven't seen that here.  It's always essential.  But they use a solid concrete barrier out there.
Do you think if you ask the Israelis if walls work, what would they say?

They would say absolutely.  Absolutely.  Obviously, it's a lot more dangerous out there.  The threat to Israelis is a lot more.  The terrorism threat is a lot higher out there.  And they're really looking to protect the IDF, Israeli Defense Forces, that patrol those areas out there.  And so that keeps them much safer.  They would get firebombed from the other side, on the Gaza side.  And so... The barrier out there, and I don't know, I can't remember how tall it is.  It's at least 30 feet high.  Oh, wow.  Concrete barrier.  So people can't throw things over it or through it in that area.  So when their IDF soldiers are patrolling, they're a lot safer.
Gotcha.

Look at the stride right here.  The area out here was littered with vehicles that came stuck out here trying to smuggle narcotics through here and they became stuck.  and they just sat out here for years and cleaned all these vehicles up all along the border and out here in this part of the desert and Welton area, the part of the desert.  there were over 80 vehicles that were abandoned out in the Welton area and we had them all cleaned up.  So we had to contract the tow company to go out, salvage company to go pick them up and take them, clean them out of the desert before we got barriers out in those areas.  Wow.
And so this goes for how long, this particular fencing?

This goes all the way to Calexico.  But this particular style, uh, stops as soon as the sand stops.  and so this sand dune area is about five miles wide and once we get past this real sandy area and it's a little firmer ground.  so a little bit farther to the west here and then you you'll see this same type of barrier but it's not the floating type it's actually um attached to the ground.  so gotcha built into the ground.
so then that actually like has concrete going down into the ground.
in other words as opposed to this one yeah we don't need it here because of the sand.  it's hard you can't dig through it.  Very interesting.  Very effective.  Wow.
And then so if we head that way, that's where the new wall construction is happening?

Yes.  So that's back towards the east, and we will go towards Andrade, California, and then on the south side of Andrade, and that turns into the Indian Reservation.  So we have two Indian Reservations here.  So that's the Kachon Indian Reservation.  And we have a camera system on the Kachon and we work with them very closely with great partners.  And then farther down river is Kokopah Indian Reservation.  We have systems on both of those.  We don't have any wall system on the Kokopah, but we do on the, on the Kachon.  And so they have a, they have a casino just north of the border and you'll see it.  You probably saw it on the way out here, but they have it, it's called the Q. And it's not very far from the border.  So that's a very popular casino, especially with the snowbirds.  And then in Algodones, Mexico is a very popular area with snowbirds because they go down there for dental work, eyeglasses, prescriptions, things of that nature down there.  So it's, it's gives a huge amount of traffic in the winter because this is a, this place gets probably doubles the population here in the winter with winter visitors to Canada and Northern States that come out here and spend the winter.  And they all go into Algodones and get a lot of this work done.  Well, just north of there is also a casino, the Indian casino.  So we've worked with the Kachan to erect a double wall system in that area, just between the US and Mexico, Algodones and Andrade.  They have appreciated because it's made things a lot safer for them.  And they're worried about potential of a robbery at the casino that gets back into Mexico quickly.  So this will help deter any of that type of activity as well.
So this is a high traffic area prior to the wall being built?  Yes.  In terms of like smuggling?
Oh, absolutely.  This area?  Absolutely.
And now not?
No.  Rarely do we get traffic out here.
